verse: At that time, Augustus Caesar sent an ·order [decree] that all people in the ·countries under Roman rule [empire; Roman world] must ·list their names in a register [register for taxation].

·This was the first registration; it was taken while Quirinius was governor of Syria [or This was the first census while Quirinius was governor of Syria; or This census occurred before Quirinius was governor of Syria].

and she gave birth to her first son. She wrapped the baby ·with pieces of cloth [in cloths; in swaddling clothes] and laid him in a ·feeding trough [manger], because there ·were no rooms [was no space/room] left in the ·inn [or guest room (of a private residence); or caravan shelter].
·That night [At night], some shepherds were [living out] in the fields ·nearby [in that region/place] watching their ·sheep [flock].
Then an angel of the Lord stood before them. The glory of the Lord ·was shining around [surrounded] them, and they became very frightened.
The angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. […for/because] I am bringing you good news that will ·be a [or bring] great joy to all the people.

·Then [And suddenly] a ·very large group [or great army] of angels from heaven ·joined [appeared with] the first angel, praising God and saying:

Everyone [who heard] ·was amazed [wondered; marveled] at what the shepherds said to them.

When ·the baby was eight days old [eight days were fulfilled; Gen. 17:12; Lev. 12:3], he was circumcised [1:59] and was named Jesus, the name given by the angel before ·the baby began to grow inside Mary [he was conceived in the womb].

header: Jesus Is Presented in the Temple

verse: When the ·time came [days were fulfilled] for ·Mary and Joseph to do what the law of Moses taught about being made pure [their purification according the law of Moses; an animal sacrifice and ritual cleansing forty days after the birth of a son; see Lev. 12:2–8], they took Jesus [up] to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord.

([Just as] It is written in the law of the Lord: “Every ·firstborn male [male who opens the womb; an idiom for a firstborn] shall be ·given [set apart; consecrated; called holy] to the Lord” [Ex. 13:2].)
Mary and Joseph also went to offer a sacrifice, as the law of the Lord says: “You must sacrifice two ·doves [or turtledoves] or two young pigeons [Lev. 5:11; 12:8].”

[Now; And behold] In Jerusalem ·lived [was] a man named Simeon who was ·a good man [righteous; just] and ·godly [devout; reverent]. He was waiting for the ·time when God would take away Israel’s sorrow [restoration/consolation of Israel; Is. 40:1] and the Holy Spirit was ·in [or upon] him.
·Simeon had been told [It had been revealed to him] by the Holy Spirit that he would not die before he saw ·the Christ promised by the Lord [the Lord’s Messiah/Anointed One].

The Spirit led Simeon to the Temple. When ·Mary and Joseph [the parents] brought the ·baby [child] Jesus to the Temple to do [for him] what ·the law said they must do [the custom of the law required],
Simeon took the baby in his arms and ·thanked [praised; blessed] God:
Jesus’ father and mother were amazed at what Simeon had said about him.

Then Simeon blessed them and said to ·Mary [his mother], “·God has chosen this child [Look/Behold, this one is destined/appointed] to cause the fall and rise of many in Israel. ·He will be a sign from God that many people will not accept […and to be a sign that is spoken against]

so that the thoughts of many [hearts] will be made known. And ·the things that will happen will make your heart sad, too [a sword will pierce your own soul; Mary will experience deep sorrow over the death of Jesus].”
There was a prophetess, ·Anna, [Hannah] ·from the family [the daughter] of Phanuel ·in [who was from] the tribe of Asher. She was very old and had once been married for seven years.

·Standing there [or Coming up to them] at that time, she ·thanked [praised; blessed] God and spoke about ·Jesus [him] to all who were waiting for ·God to free [the redemption/deliverance of] Jerusalem.
When Joseph and Mary had done everything the law of the Lord commanded, they went home to Nazareth, their own town in Galilee [Matt. 2:22–23].
The little child grew and became strong. He was filled with wisdom, and God’s ·goodness [favor; grace] was upon him.
Every year Jesus’ parents went to Jerusalem for the Passover ·Feast [festival; annual festival that celebrates God’s rescue of Israel from Egypt; Ex. 12].
When he was twelve years old, they went to the ·feast [festival] ·as they always did [or according to Jewish custom].
After the feast days were over, they started home. The boy Jesus stayed behind in Jerusalem, but his parents did not know it.
Thinking that Jesus was with them in the group, they traveled for a whole day. Then they began to look for him among their family and friends.
When they did not find him, they went back to Jerusalem to look for him there.

After three days [probably three days since they left Jerusalem—one out, one back, and one searching] they found Jesus sitting in the Temple ·with [among; in the middle of] the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions.
All who heard him were amazed at his understanding and answers.
